6.summary: Drawing from Al-Mizan, Allama Tabatabai explains that elucidates that the "heaviness" of scales transcends mere quantitative reckoning of deeds, instead symbolizing the intrinsic weight of spiritual realities shaped by faith (iman) and divine recognition (ma'rifah). In Surah Al-Qaari'a, verse 6, Allah declares: *Fa-ammā man thaqulat mawāzīnuhu* – "Then as for one whose scales are heavy [with good deeds]. " This verse forms part of a vivid depiction of the Day of Judgment, where every soul’s deeds are weighed. The term *mawazin* (scales) symbolizes divine justice, measuring not merely the quantity but the *quality* and sincerity of actions. Imam Sadiq (as) teaches, "The weightiest thing placed on the Scale is love for us Ahlul Bayt, for it is the essence of every good deed. this verse invites self-reflection: Are our prayers, charity, and ethics performed to earn divine pleasure or social validation? It challenges us to integrate the Ahlul Bayt’s teachings into daily life—treating others justly, resisting oppression, and nurturing inner purity.

7.layer1:
In Surah Al-Qaari’a, verse 7 describes the eternal reward awaiting the righteous: *fa huwa fi ‘ishatin radiya* (“He will be in a pleasant life”). This verse concludes a vivid depiction of the Day of Judgment, contrasting the fate of those whose good deeds “weigh heavy” on the scales of divine justice with those whose deeds are found lacking. The “pleasant life” here refers to the perfected state of contentment in Paradise, where believers experience both physical and spiritual fulfillment. Classical Shia tafsir, such as Allamah Tabatabai’s *Al-Mizan*, emphasizes that *‘ishatin radiya* transcends earthly pleasures, representing eternal harmony with Allah’s will and proximity to the Divine Presence. The term *radiya* (pleased/satisfied) signifies a mutual state: Allah is pleased with the believer, and the believer is satisfied with their Lord’s decree—a concept echoed in the teachings of Imam Ali, who described Paradise as “the abode of everlasting joy” (*Nahj al-Balagha*).

Historically, this Meccan surah was revealed during intense persecution of early Muslims, offering hope by affirming that ultimate justice lies with Allah. The “pleasant life” reassures believers that temporary worldly struggles are outweighed by eternal reward. Key Arabic terms like *‘isha* (life/livelihood) and *radi* (contentment) highlight the holistic nature of this reward—a life free from want, anxiety, or dissatisfaction, rooted in divine grace. 

For contemporary Muslims, this verse invites reflection on aligning one’s life with eternal goals. It encourages prioritizing deeds that “weigh heavy” on the scales—acts of justice, compassion, and devotion—while cultivating inner contentment (*rida*) through trust in Allah’s plan. In a world fixated on material success, this verse reminds believers that true fulfillment lies in spiritual purpose and the pursuit of Paradise, where the faithful will dwell in a state of perfect peace, embraced by Allah’s eternal pleasure.
7.layer2:
In interpreting Surah al-Qaari’a 101:7, classical Shia exegetes emphasize the ontological and spiritual dimensions of the "pleasant life" (عيشة راضية) promised to the righteous. Allama Tabatabai, in *Al-Mizan*, contextualizes this verse within the surah’s eschatological framework, noting that the "pleasant life" emerges as a direct consequence of one’s deeds being "found weighty" on the Divine Scale (101:6-7). He identifies this state as an eternal existence in Paradise, marked by divine proximity (qurb) and free from all worldly limitations, where the soul attains perfect contentment (rida) through alignment with Allah’s will. This rida is bidirectional: the believer is both "pleased" with their Lord’s decree and "pleasing" to Him—a reciprocity rooted in Qur’anic theology (e.g., 89:27-30) and amplified in Shia narrations.

Tabrisi, in *Majma al-Bayan*, highlights the linguistic nuance of radiyya (راضية), derived from rida, which signifies a state of ultimate satisfaction transcending physical comforts. He cites traditions linking this reward to the recognition and love (mahabba) of the Ahl al-Bayt, reflecting the Shia theological axiom that salvation hinges on wilaya (allegiance to divine guardianship). The "pleasant life" thus becomes inseparable from the believer’s connection to the Imams, who serve as both guides in this world and intercessors in the hereafter. 

This interpretation aligns with Shia soteriology, wherein righteous actions—though necessary—are insufficient without adherence to the divinely appointed Imamate. The verse’s promise of eternal fulfillment thereby intertwines ethical rigor with metaphysical truth, affirming the Shia paradigm of harmonizing works (‘amal) with creed (‘aqida). Such exegesis underscores the inseparability of Qur’anic eschatology from the foundational Shia doctrine of Imamah, as articulated in classical sources.
7.layer3:
In contemporary Shia scholarship, Surah Al-Qaari’a’s description of a “pleasant life” (ʿīshatin rāḍiya) is often interpreted as a holistic state of fulfillment transcending material comfort. Ayatollah Naser Makarem Shirazi, in his *Tafsir Nemuneh*, emphasizes that this “pleasant life” reflects both eternal Paradise and the inner tranquility achieved through ethical living and proximity to God. Modern scholars like Dr. Mohammad Ali Shomali connect this to psychological well-being, noting that neuroscience confirms how altruism, gratitude, and spiritual practices activate brain regions linked to lasting happiness—aligning with the Quranic vision of contentment rooted in faith and moral action.

Philosophically, the verse challenges consumerist notions of success. Scholars such as Sayyid Ammar Nakshawani argue that in an age of climate crises and inequality, true “pleasantness” arises from sustainable living and social equity, echoing Imam Ali’s teachings on balancing material and spiritual needs. The verse thus becomes a call to address modern dysfunctions—isolation, environmental degradation, and wealth disparity—by recentering community welfare and divine accountability.

Interfaith dialogues highlight parallels: Buddhist mindfulness, Christian “peace that surpasses understanding,” and secular humanism’s focus on collective flourishing all resonate with this Quranic ideal. Yet Shia thought uniquely ties this fulfillment to divine justice—exemplified by Imam Hussain’s stand against oppression—underscoring that societal reform and personal piety are inseparable. In a multicultural world, the verse invites universal reflection: What defines a “pleasant life,” and how can shared values bridge divides? For Shia Muslims, the answer lies in harmonizing timeless revelation with contemporary struggles for dignity and balance.
7.layer4:
The verse "He will be in a pleasant life" (101:7) transcends the mere description of Paradise’s physical comforts. According to the teachings of the Ahlul Bayt (peace be upon them), this "pleasant life" signifies a profound spiritual state rooted in divine proximity and the recognition of *Wilayah* (divine guardianship). Imam Muhammad al-Baqir (peace be upon him) taught that the true "pleasant life" is attained through unwavering love for the Ahlul Bayt and adherence to their guidance, for they are the gateways to Allah’s mercy.  

In *Tafsir al-Qummi*, Imam Ja’far al-Sadiq (peace be upon him) explains that this verse refers to those whose hearts are illuminated by the light of Imamah. Their contentment arises not from material ease but from the certitude (*yaqeen*) that comes from submitting to Allah’s chosen guides. Lady Fatimah (peace be upon her) emphasized in her renowned sermon that the hereafter’s rewards are shaped by one’s deeds and connection to divine truth: "The most beloved servant to Allah is the one who follows His commands and sees with the light of His guidance."  

The "pleasant life" is thus a state of inner tranquility achieved by aligning one’s soul with the Imams’ purified teachings. Practical steps to attain this include daily remembrance (*dhikr*) of Allah, seeking intercession (*tawassul*) through the Ahlul Bayt, and embodying justice and compassion as exemplified by Imam Ali (peace be upon him). Imam al-Sadiq taught, "The believer’s heart is a throne for the Divine Light—polish it with piety and love for us."  

Ultimately, this verse invites believers to transform their lives into a continuous worship grounded in *Wilayah*, for true satisfaction lies in nearness to Allah through devotion to His Proofs (*Hujjah*) on earth. As Imam Ali said, "The soul of the righteous is a bird flying in the gardens of eternity.

7.layer5:
The interpretation of Surah al-Qari'a 7 ("He will be in a pleasant life") reveals both shared eschatological principles and nuanced differences between Shia and Sunni exegetical traditions. Classical scholars across both schools concur that the verse describes the eternal reward for those whose good deeds outweigh their misdeeds on the Day of Judgment, understood as the bliss of Paradise. Al-Tabari (Sunni) and al-Tabrisi (Shia) both emphasize "pleasant life" (عيشة راضية) as divine satisfaction and eternal contentment, citing linguistic parallels to Quranic descriptions of Paradise (e.g., 69:21). Ibn Kathir and al-Tusi similarly align in viewing this state as a culmination of divine mercy granted to the righteous.

Divergent interpretations emerge in conceptualizing the nature of this reward. Sunni commentators like al-Qurtubi and al-Razi focus on the experiential aspects of Paradise, emphasizing sensory delights and spiritual fulfillment attained through individual accountability and adherence to prophetic Sunnah. In contrast, Shia sources such as al-Mizan and Tafsir al-Qummi often contextualize the verse within the framework of walaya (devotion to the Ahl al-Bayt). Al-Tabatabai posits that true "contentment" arises from proximity to the Divine through the Imams, interpreting the verse as an affirmation of the Shia theological principle that spiritual fulfillment is inseparable from allegiance to the Prophet’s household.

These differences stem from distinct hermeneutical approaches: Sunni tafsir prioritizes textual literalism and consensus (ijma), while Shia exegesis frequently incorporates hadiths from the Imams as interpretive authorities. Historically, this reflects the Shia emphasis on the Ahl al-Bayt’s role as spiritual and exegetical guides post-Prophet Muhammad. Both traditions, however, agree that the verse underscores the Quran’s core message of eschatological justice, with practical implications for cultivating piety and ethical conduct. While interpretations vary in emphasis, they collectively affirm the verse’s function as a moral incentive and a theological assurance of divine recompense.

7.summary: As articulated in Tafsir al-Mizan, contextualizes this verse within the surah’s eschatological framework, noting that the "pleasant life" emerges as a direct consequence of one’s deeds being "found weighty" on the Divine Scale (101:6-7). In Surah Al-Qaari’a, verse 7 describes the eternal reward awaiting the righteous: *fa huwa fi ‘ishatin radiya* (“He will be in a pleasant life”). This verse concludes a vivid depiction of the Day of Judgment, contrasting the fate of those whose good deeds “weigh heavy” on the scales of divine justice with those whose deeds are found lacking. The “pleasant life” here refers to the perfected state of contentment in Paradise, where believers experience both physical and spiritual fulfillment. Imam Muhammad al-Baqir (peace be upon him) taught that the true "pleasant life" is attained through unwavering love for the Ahlul Bayt and adherence to their guidance, for they are the gateways to Allah’s mercy. this verse invites reflection on aligning one’s life with eternal goals.

8.layer1:
In Surah Al-Qaari’a, verse 8, Allah states, *“Wa amma man khaffat mawazinuhu”* (“But as for one whose scales are light”), presenting a profound metaphor for divine judgment. The term *mawazin* (scales) symbolizes the evaluation of deeds on the Day of Resurrection, a concept deeply rooted in Shia tafsir. Classical commentators like Allama Tabatabai in *Tafsir al-Mizan* explain that these “scales” are not physical but represent the spiritual weight of a person’s actions, measured by their sincerity, alignment with divine guidance, and adherence to the teachings of the Ahlul Bayt. The word *khaffat* (light) signifies a deficiency in righteous deeds or the dominance of sins, indicating a soul’s failure to cultivate spiritual substance through faith and ethical conduct.

Revealed in Mecca during a period of intense opposition to the Prophet Muhammad (PBUH), this verse served as a reminder of individual accountability amid a society preoccupied with materialism and tribal pride. It challenged listeners to reflect on the transient nature of worldly status and the eternal consequences of their choices. The “light scales” warn against hollow rituals, arrogance, and neglect of moral duties—a message resonating across time.

In Shia theology, the “weight” of deeds is intrinsically tied to loyalty (*walaya*) to the Ahlul Bayt, whose teachings illuminate the path to righteousness. Imam Ali emphasized that deeds devoid of sincere intention or divorced from divine guidance are “like scattered dust,” lacking true value. Today, this verse urges Muslims to prioritize quality over quantity in worship, infusing acts like prayer, charity, and justice with consciousness of Allah and compassion for others. It calls for self-assessment: Are our deeds rooted in ego or service? Do they align with Quranic principles and the example of the Prophet’s household? In an age of superficiality, this verse is a timeless anchor, reminding believers that true success lies in nurturing a soul heavy with faith, humility, and love for truth.
8.layer2:
In Surah Al-Qari'a, verse 8, the Qur'an presents a stark dichotomy between those whose "scales are heavy" and those whose "scales are light" on the Day of Judgment. Classical Shia exegetes, drawing from the teachings of the Ahlul Bayt, interpret the "scales" (mawazin) as a metaphysical measure of human deeds, intentions, and spiritual alignment with divine truth. As Imam Jafar al-Sadiq states in traditions cited by Tabrisi in *Majma al-Bayan*, the "lightness" of scales signifies not merely a quantitative deficit in good deeds but a qualitative failure to harmonize one’s actions with the principles of *tawhid* (divine unity) and *wilayah* (allegiance to the divinely appointed Imams). 

Tabatabai’s *Al-Mizan* emphasizes that the scales symbolize divine justice, wherein deeds are weighed according to their conformity to the *maʿrifa* (recognition) of God and the prophetic mission. A "light" scale thus reflects the soul’s detachment from the transformative power of faith—a concept rooted in the Qur'anic principle that deeds devoid of *iman* (faith) and *ihsan* (spiritual excellence) hold no weight in the hereafter. Shia theology uniquely posits that acknowledgment of the Imams’ guardianship is inseparable from this spiritual calculus, as they represent the "balance" (*mizan*) of truth in creation (Qur'an 42:17). 

Tabrisi further notes that the verse’s warning extends to those who neglect obligations (*faraid*) or violate ethical boundaries (*hudud*), underscoring the interdependence of creed and jurisprudence. The "lightness" of scales thus encompasses both doctrinal deviation and moral bankruptcy, reflecting the Shia view that true faith necessitates adherence to the *usul* (principles) and *furuʿ* (practices) of religion as preserved by the Ahlul Bayt. This interpretation aligns with the broader Shia doctrine of *thaqalayn*—the inseparable bond between the Qur'an and the Prophet’s progeny—as the foundation for salvation.
8.layer3:
In contemporary Shia scholarship, Surah Al-Qaari’a’s imagery of “light scales” is often interpreted through the lens of ethical accountability and existential purpose. Ayatollah Nasir Makarim Shirazi, in his *Tafsir Nemuneh*, frames the “scales” (mawazin) not merely as a literal measure of deeds but as a metaphor for the alignment between human actions and divine justice—a balance between material pursuits and spiritual consciousness. Modern scholars like Dr. Mohammad Ali Shomali extend this, arguing that “lightness” reflects a life disconnected from transcendent values, such as ecological neglect, social apathy, or systemic greed, which destabilise both individual and collective equilibrium.  

Scientific insights into interconnected systems—ecological, economic, or neurological—resonate here. The Quranic “balance” (mizan) mirrors contemporary understandings of sustainability: just as ecosystems collapse when natural equilibria are disrupted, societal harmony fractures when moral and material priorities are misaligned. Climate activists like those inspired by Imam Ali’s (“People are either your brothers in faith or equals in humanity”) ethic link environmental stewardship to the “weight” of responsibility in this verse.  

Socially, the verse critiques modern individualism. Scholars such as Sayyid Ammar Nakshawani connect “light scales” to the erosion of community bonds in hyper-capitalist societies, where wealth accumulation often overshadows empathy or charity. Philosophically, it challenges existential nihilism; the “lightness” signifies a life devoid of higher meaning, akin to philosopher Albert Camus’ “absurd,” but countered by the Quranic call to purposeful action.  

In multicultural contexts, interfaith dialogues highlight shared Abrahamic emphases on justice—Jewish *tzedakah*, Christian *agape*, and Islamic *zakat* all “weigh” compassion against indifference. For a world grappling with inequality and climate crises, this verse becomes a timeless prompt: How do we add “weight” to our lives through service, integrity, and reverence for life’s sacred balance?
8.layer4:
In the cosmic balance of Qiyamah described in Surah Al-Qaari'a, the verse "But as for one whose scales are light" unveils profound spiritual truths through the lens of Ahlul Bayt's teachings. Imam Ja'far al-Sadiq (peace be upon him) illuminates that "the scales are not of iron and weights, but of divine justice measured through love (mahabba) and recognition (ma'rifah) of Wilayah." The lightness signifies a soul's poverty in spiritual substance - not merely a deficit in ritual acts, but a failure to anchor one's existence in the luminous reality of Imamah.

Lady Fatimah Zahra (peace be upon her) warns in her historic sermon: "The lightest scales on Judgment Day will belong to those whose tongues praised Allah but whose hearts denied His chosen ones." This echoes Imam Ali's (peace be upon him) teaching that "Actions are lifeless forms until animated by the spirit of sincere love for us, the Ahlul Bayt." The scales weigh not just deeds, but the divine light within those deeds - light kindled through conscious connection to the Muhammadan Reality embodied in the Fourteen Infallibles.

Practical spirituality emerges through Imam al-Baqir's (peace be upon him) guidance: "Make your scales heavy with the weight of tears shed in longing for Husayn, with nights spent in communion through Nawafil, and with days spent upholding justice as taught by Ali." The antidote to "light scales" lies in transforming every prayer into a mirror reflecting the Imam's countenance, every ethical choice into allegiance to divine guardianship, and every moment into an opportunity for witnessing the Nur of Ahlul Bayt in creation.

Thus, the verse becomes a compass directing believers toward the harbor of Wilayah - where actions gain weight through their resonance with the cosmic mission of the Imams, where spiritual poverty is remedied by drinking from the fountain of their eternal wisdom, and where the soul's gravity is measured by its proximity to the Throne of Divine Mercy embodied in Muhammad's purified progeny.

8.layer5:
In analyzing Surah al-Qari'a verse 8, both Shia and Sunni scholarly traditions recognize the verse’s eschatological significance, emphasizing divine justice and the accountability of human deeds on the Day of Judgment. Sunni commentators like Tabari and Ibn Kathir (Jami al-Bayan, Tafsir al-Quran al-Azim) broadly concur with Shia exegetes such as Tabatabai (Al-Mizan) and Tabrisi (Majma al-Bayan) that "scales" (mawazin) symbolize the evaluation of moral and spiritual actions, with "light scales" denoting deficient righteous deeds. Both traditions cite prophetic hadiths and Quranic parallels (e.g., 7:8-9, 23:102-103) to affirm the principle of divine recompense proportionate to human conduct.

A key divergence lies in the ontological nature of the "scales." Sunni scholars like Qurtubi (Al-Jami li-Ahkam) and Razi (Mafatih al-Ghayb) often emphasize a literal interpretation, framing mawazin as physical instruments weighing deeds—a view rooted in Sunni literalism regarding resurrection’s corporeal aspects. In contrast, Shia tafsirs, particularly Al-Mizan, frequently interpret the metaphor more transcendentally, stressing that deeds’ intrinsic spiritual "weight" reflects their alignment with divine truth (haqq) and the guidance of the Ahl al-Bayt. Tusi (At-Tibyan) and Qummi (Tafsir al-Qummi) further link "light scales" to deficient recognition (maʿrifa) of legitimate authority (wilaya), integrating Imamology into eschatological outcomes.

These differences stem from distinct theological frameworks: Sunni exegesis often prioritizes individual accountability and ritual adherence, while Shia interpretations intertwine ethical action with allegiance to the Imams as spiritual guarantors. Historically, such variations reflect early Islamic debates about authority and the nature of religious guidance post-Prophet Muhammad. Both traditions, however, converge on the verse’s core ethical imperative: cultivating God-consciousness through righteous deeds, demonstrating how shared Quranic principles manifest across interpretive schools.

8.summary: Classical Shia exegetes, drawing from the teachings of the Ahlul Bayt, interpret the "scales" (mawazin) as a metaphysical measure of human deeds, intentions, and spiritual alignment with divine truth. In Surah Al-Qaari’a, verse 8, Allah states, *“Wa amma man khaffat mawazinuhu”* (“But as for one whose scales are light”), presenting a profound metaphor for divine judgment. The term *mawazin* (scales) symbolizes the evaluation of deeds on the Day of Resurrection, a concept deeply rooted in Shia tafsir. Classical commentators like Allama Tabatabai in *Tafsir al-Mizan* explain that these “scales” are not physical but represent the spiritual weight of a person’s actions, measured by their sincerity, alignment with divine guidance, and adherence to the teachings of the Ahlul Bayt. Imam Ja'far al-Sadiq (peace be upon him) illuminates that "the scales are not of iron and weights, but of divine justice measured through love (mahabba) and recognition (ma'rifah) of Wilayah. It calls for self-assessment: Are our deeds rooted in ego or service? Do they align with Quranic principles and the example of the Prophet’s household? In an age of superficiality, this verse is a timeless anchor, reminding believers that true success lies in nurturing a soul heavy with faith, humility, and love for truth.

9.layer1:
In Surah Al-Qaari’a, verse 9, Allah declares, *“Fa-ummuhu hawiyah”* (His refuge will be an abyss), a vivid depiction of the fate awaiting those whose evil deeds dominate their lives. The term *“umm”* (mother) here is symbolic, referring not to a literal parent but to one’s ultimate destination or “source” of return—a metaphor rooted in classical Arabic. The word *“hawiyah”* derives from the root *h-w-y*, meaning “to fall” or “to collapse,” evoking the image of a bottomless pit. Shia scholars like Allamah Tabatabai in *Al-Mizan* explain this as a reference to Hell, the final abode of those who reject truth and live heedlessly.  

This Meccan surah emphasizes the Day of Judgment, urging listeners to reflect on eternal consequences. Historical accounts note its revelation during a period when early Muslims faced intense persecution, serving as both a warning to oppressors and a reassurance to the faithful. The verse’s power lies in its contrast: while the righteous are promised divine reward (v. 6-7), the unjust face *hawiyah*—a term Imam Ali (as) described in Nahj al-Balagha as “the ruin of those who prioritize worldly desires over spiritual growth.”  

For contemporary Muslims, this verse underscores the urgency of ethical accountability. In a world distracted by materialism, it reminds us that every choice shapes our eternal *“umm”*—our final home. Practically, this calls for daily self-assessment: Are our actions aligning with divine scales of justice? Are we nurturing compassion, honesty, and humility, or allowing greed and arrogance to pull us toward spiritual collapse? By internalizing this warning, believers can strive to live with *tawqa* (God-consciousness), seeking refuge not in fleeting pursuits but in the mercy of Allah and the guidance of the Ahlul Bayt (as), who illuminate the path away from *hawiyah* and toward eternal light.
9.layer2:
In Surah al-Qaari'a (101:9), the declaration *fa-ummuhu hawiyah* ("His refuge will be an abyss") presents a profound theological and eschatological imagery central to Shia exegesis. Classical commentators, drawing from the teachings of the Ahlul Bayt, interpret *hawiyah* as a reference to the lowest depths of Hell, symbolising both physical and spiritual annihilation. Al-Tabrisi in *Majma al-Bayan* elucidates that *hawiyah* denotes a "pit of destruction" (hufrat al-halaka), emphasising its linguistic root (*h-w-y*) connoting falling or collapsing into ruin. This aligns with the Shia understanding of divine justice (*‘adl*), wherein one’s deeds determine their eternal abode—a principle reiterated in numerous narrations from Imam Jafar al-Sadiq, who taught that the verse underscores the gravity of moral accountability.

Al-Tabrisi further notes that the term *umm* (lit. "mother") here metaphorically signifies "final destination" or "source of return," reflecting a recurring Quranic motif where spiritual realities are expressed through familial analogies (e.g., *Umm al-Kitab*). This interpretation is corroborated in Al-Tabtabai’s *Al-Mizan*, which explains that the "abyss" represents the ultimate consequence of rejecting truth—a state of existential disintegration mirroring the soul’s alienation from divine mercy. The Shia tradition uniquely links such eschatological outcomes to the recognition (*ma‘rifa*) and allegiance (*walaya*) to the Imams, as articulated in hadiths describing Hell as the refuge of those who oppose the Ahlul Bayt.

Theologically, this verse intersects with Shia doctrines of resurrection (*ma‘ad*) and the intercessory role of the Imams, who, as per narrations in *Bihar al-Anwar*, act as mediators for those grounded in faith. The "abyss" thus serves not merely as a punitive metaphor but as a ontological reality for souls severed from the luminous guidance of the Prophetic legacy. Such interpretations reinforce the Shia emphasis on ethical and doctrinal fidelity, situating individual accountability within the framework of divine covenant (*mithaq*) and the cosmic balance of deeds.
9.layer3:
In contemporary Shia scholarship, Surah Al-Qaari’a’s imagery of the “abyss” (hawiyah) as a refuge for those whose deeds are spiritually weightless is interpreted through both existential and societal lenses. Ayatollah Nasir Makarem Shirazi notes that *hawiyah*—often classically understood as Hell—symbolizes the collapse of moral foundations, where one’s “mother” (umm) metaphorically becomes the abyss, reflecting a return to the root of one’s spiritual bankruptcy. This duality of “mother” as source and destruction underscores the tragedy of self-created ruin.  

Modern thinkers like Dr. Mohammad Ali Shomali connect this to today’s existential crises: the abyss mirrors the void felt in hyper-materialist societies, where disconnection from divine purpose leads to psychological fragmentation. Neuroscientific studies on despair align with this, showing how ethical decay correlates with mental health decline—a literal “weighing light” of the soul.  

Socially, the verse critiques systemic injustice. Scholar Fatima Haeri links *hawiyah* to structures trapping marginalized communities in cycles of poverty or oppression, framing hell as both otherworldly and man-made. Climate collapse, driven by greed, becomes a tangible “abyss,” echoing the Quranic warning that exploitation rebounds as existential threat.  

Interfaith dialogues highlight parallels: Buddhist “Naraka” (hell realms) arising from karma, or Christian notions of separation from God. Yet Shia theology emphasizes *tawhid*’s integrative power—urging balance between material and spiritual to avoid the abyss. In a multicultural world, this verse becomes a universal call to cultivate weighted deeds: justice, compassion, and ecological stewardship as anchors against collective freefall.
9.layer4:
The verse "His refuge will be an abyss" (101:9) pierces the heart with a profound warning about the spiritual consequences of rejecting divine truth. The Ahlul Bayt (peace be upon them) taught that "Hawiya" (the abyss) is not merely a physical pit but the crushing emptiness of a soul severed from the light of *Wilayah* (divine guardianship). Imam Ali (peace be upon him) states, "The heart that lacks recognition of its Imam becomes a ruin, haunted by the winds of misguidance" (*Bihar al-Anwar*). Here, the "abyss" symbolizes the soul’s collapse into spiritual bankruptcy when it denies the guidance of the Imams, who are the manifest ropes of Allah’s mercy.  

Lady Fatimah (peace be upon her) illuminates this verse’s deeper meaning in her famed sermon: "Allah made faith your purification from polytheism, prayer your elevation from arrogance, and *Wilayah* your salvation from the abyss" (*Balaghat al-Fatimiyyah*). The "abyss" thus represents the soul’s freefall into darkness when it neglects its covenant with the divine *Imamah*. Imam Ja’far al-Sadiq (peace be upon him) explains, "On Judgment Day, deeds will take form: the deeds of the ignorant will appear as hollow pits, while the deeds of the lovers of the Ahlul Bayt will shine like full moons" (*Tafsir al-Qummi*).  

Practically, this verse calls believers to anchor their hearts in the love and obedience of the Imams. Daily *dhikr* of the Ahlul Bayt, sincere repentance, and emulating their ethical conduct fortify the soul against the abyss. Imam Ali (peace be upon him) advises, "Fill your inner void with remembrance of Allah and love for His Chosen Ones, lest it become a chasm that swallows your light" (*Nahj al-Balagha*). True refuge lies in clinging to the *Thaqalayn*—the Quran and the sinless Imams—whose guidance transforms the abyss into a bridge to divine proximity.

9.layer5:
In examining Surah al-Qari'a 101:9, both Shia and Sunni scholarly traditions converge on interpreting "Hawiya" (the abyss) as a vivid metaphor for Hell’s torment awaiting those whose evil deeds outweigh their good. Al-Tabari (Sunni) and Al-Tabrisi (Shia) both emphasize the verse’s eschatological context, linking it to the Quranic principle of divine recompense (jazā’) on Judgment Day. Al-Qurtubi and Al-Tusi similarly note the linguistic force of "Ummuhu" (his mother) as symbolizing ultimate归宿 (return/destination), drawing parallels to Arabic idioms where "mother" denotes origin or final state. This shared understanding reinforces core Islamic beliefs about accountability and the afterlife’s reality.

Key divergences emerge in theological emphasis. Sunni exegetes like Ibn Kathir and Al-Razi focus on individual moral responsibility, interpreting "Hawiya" as the natural consequence of rejecting faith and ethical obligations. In contrast, Shia commentaries such as Al-Mizan (Tabatabai) and Tafsir al-Qummi often contextualize the verse within the framework of divine justice (‘adl), stressing that rejection of divinely appointed guidance (e.g., the Imams) exacerbates one’s spiritual downfall. Al-Tibyan (Al-Tusi) further highlights the abyss as a state of existential alienation from the Ahl al-Bayt’s intercessory role, a perspective rooted in Shia soteriology.

These differences reflect distinct theological priorities: Sunni interpretations often prioritize individual action and divine omnipotence, while Shia readings integrate Imamah into eschatological outcomes. Historically, these divergences arose from early debates about leadership and spiritual authority post-Prophet Muhammad, crystallizing into distinct hermeneutical lenses. Both traditions, however, agree the verse serves as a moral catalyst, urging believers toward piety—a unity of purpose transcending interpretive variations.

9.summary: This interpretation is corroborated in Al-Tabtabai’s *Al-Mizan*, which explains that the "abyss" represents the ultimate consequence of rejecting truth—a state of existential disintegration mirroring the soul’s alienation from divine mercy. In Surah Al-Qaari’a, verse 9, Allah declares, *“Fa-ummuhu hawiyah”* (His refuge will be an abyss), a vivid depiction of the fate awaiting those whose evil deeds dominate their lives. The term *“umm”* (mother) here is symbolic, referring not to a literal parent but to one’s ultimate destination or “source” of return—a metaphor rooted in classical Arabic. The word *“hawiyah”* derives from the root *h-w-y*, meaning “to fall” or “to collapse,” evoking the image of a bottomless pit. Imam Ali (peace be upon him) states, "The heart that lacks recognition of its Imam becomes a ruin, haunted by the winds of misguidance" (*Bihar al-Anwar*). believers can strive to live with *tawqa* (God-consciousness), seeking refuge not in fleeting pursuits but in the mercy of Allah and the guidance of the Ahlul Bayt (as), who illuminate the path away from *hawiyah* and toward eternal light.

10.layer1:
The verse "وَمَآ أَدْرَىٰكَ مَا هِيَهْ" (And what can make you know what that is?) from Surah Al-Qaari'a employs a rhetorical style common in early Meccan revelations, challenging human limitations in grasping divine realities. Revealed during intense opposition to the Prophet’s message, this surah focuses on the Day of Judgment – called *Al-Qaari'a* (The Striking Calamity) – to awaken its original audience to life’s transient nature and the certainty of resurrection. The repeated phrase "ما أدرىٰك" (what makes you know) underscores humanity’s inability to comprehend cosmic truths without divine guidance, a theme echoed in Shia exegesis like Allamah Tabatabai’s *Al-Mizan*, which notes that such verses humble human intellect while affirming the necessity of prophetic revelation.

The word *هِيَهْ* (hiyah) refers to the apocalyptic event described in preceding verses – a cataclysmic reordering of existence where deeds are weighed and souls face eternal consequences. Classical commentators like Shaykh Tusi emphasise that this phrasing invites reflection on the *ghayb* (unseen) realities accessible only through Allah’s disclosure via the Quran and the Ahlul Bayt. The rhetorical question isn’t seeking information but reinforcing that true understanding flows from submission to divine wisdom, not worldly reasoning.

For contemporary Muslims, this verse cultivates humility in an age of information overload. It reminds believers to anchor their understanding of life’s purpose and the afterlife in Quranic teachings and the guidance of the Imams, rather than relying solely on materialist logic. Practically, this means prioritising spiritual preparation over worldly distractions, viewing daily choices through the lens of eternal accountability, and trusting in transmitted wisdom when facing existential questions. By internalising the lesson that "what makes you know" comes from Allah, Muslims nurture *tawakkul* (trust in God) while actively seeking knowledge through authentic religious sources.
10.layer2:
In Surah Al-Qaari'a, verse 10, Allah’s rhetorical question, *“And what can make you know what that is?”* serves to emphasize the profound inaccessibility of the Day of Judgment’s reality to unaided human comprehension. Classical Shia exegetes, such as Allama Tabatabai in *Al-Mizan*, interpret this verse as a deliberate provocation to awaken humanity to its epistemic limitations regarding divine realities. Tabatabai notes that the interrogative form here is not a request for information but a literary device to underscore the magnitude and terror of *al-Qaari'a* (the Striking Calamity), a term denoting the cataclysmic events of the Hereafter. The verse, he argues, situates human knowledge as inherently contingent, dependent on divine revelation and the teachings of the Ahlul Bayt, who alone possess the *ta’wil* (esoteric interpretation) of such metaphysical truths.

Similarly, Sheikh Tabrisi’s *Majma al-Bayan* highlights the linguistic force of *“ma adraka”* (what makes you know), a Quranic formula reserved for concepts beyond ordinary perception, such as the Hour’s timing or the nature of divine punishment. Tabrisi contextualizes this within the Shia theological framework of *ma’ad* (resurrection), stressing that while the event’s inevitability is rationally established through Quranic proofs, its essence remains veiled except to those granted *‘ilm ladunni* (knowledge from the Divine Presence). This aligns with the Shia doctrine that the Imams, as inheritors of the Prophet’s *‘ilm*, illuminate such obscured truths for the faithful.

The verse also implicitly reinforces the Shia emphasis on the necessity of *walaya* (divinely ordained guardianship), as the Ahlul Bayt’s teachings alone bridge the gap between human limitation and divine reality. This theological nexus between eschatology and Imamology underscores a core Shia tenet: the recognition of the Imams’ role as guides to transcendent truths, without which the believer’s understanding of Quranic eschatology remains incomplete. Thus, the verse subtly affirms the interdependence of Quranic revelation and prophetic authority, a principle foundational to Shia jurisprudence and creed.
10.layer3:
In Surah Al-Qari’a’s haunting question—“What can make you know what that is?”—contemporary Shia scholars like Ayatollah Nasir Makarim Shirazi emphasize the verse’s timeless call to epistemic humility. The “that” refers to the Day of Judgment, a reality beyond human conceptual limits, echoing Imam Ali’s counsel in *Nahj al-Balagha*: “The unseen is known only to Allah.” Today, this verse resonates with scientific humility—acknowledging the mysteries of dark energy, quantum indeterminacy, or the origins of consciousness—reminding us that human knowledge, while vast, remains bounded. As physicist Carlo Rovelli notes, “Every answer unveils new questions,” mirroring the Quranic principle that divine reality transcends human grasp.

Socially, the verse critiques modern hubris: climate collapse, AI ethics, and economic inequity often stem from humanity’s delusion of mastery. Scholar Sayyid Muhammad Husayn Fadlallah linked such Quranic warnings to the need for ethical stewardship, urging societies to balance progress with reverence for the unknown. Philosophically, it aligns with postmodern critiques of absolute truths, inviting dialogue with interfaith perspectives—Buddhist impermanence, Jewish divine mystery, or Indigenous cosmologies—that similarly honor the limits of human understanding.

In a fractured world, this verse becomes a bridge: it challenges materialist arrogance while fostering solidarity through shared vulnerability. As Shia theology teaches, the Mahdi’s eventual reappearance will resolve cosmic truths, but until then, humility before the unseen remains a moral compass. Whether addressing CRISPR ethics or interfaith tensions, the verse invites humanity to replace certitude with awe, aligning progress with divine wisdom.
10.layer4:
The verse "And what can make you know what that is?" (101:10) pierces the veil of human limitation, calling believers to recognize their dependence on divine guidance to comprehend the terrifying reality of Al-Qari'a (the Striking Day). Imam Ali (as) taught, "The reality of the Hour is known only to the One who created it, but He has placed its keys in the hearts of His proofs [the Ahlul Bayt]." This establishes that true understanding of eschatological truths flows through the channel of Imamah.  

In Tafsir al-Burhan, Imam Ja'far al-Sadiq (as) explains this verse as a profound awakening: "It is a call to the soul – do you presume to grasp the magnitude of divine reckoning without the light of Wilayah?" The Imam (as) further states, "The Striking Day strikes hearts before it strikes creation; only those nourished by the springs of our love will find it coolness rather than fire." Here, the Imam connects comprehension of the Hereafter to spiritual preparation through attachment to the Ahlul Bayt.  

Lady Fatimah (as) illuminated this truth in her famous sermon: "The Day of Qari'a makes heavy what the ignorant consider light – it weighs allegiance to truth against hollow deeds." This emphasizes that true awareness comes not through intellectual speculation, but through lived commitment to the path of the purified ones.  

Practical guidance emerges: To "know what it is," one must anchor in the Ark of Salvation. Daily recitation of Dua al-Ahd renews our covenant with the Imam of our time. Reflection upon Imam Zayn al-Abidin's (as) *Supplication for the Day of Arafa* trains the soul to perceive the spiritual earthquakes of Qari'a. Let every prayer include the plea: "O Allah, make my scales heavy with love for those whose love You made weightier than all deeds."  

Ultimately, this verse reminds us that the terror of Qari'a transforms into mercy for those who recognize the *Noor* of Muhammad and his Family – for as the Prophet (pbuh) said, "They are the Ark: whoever boards it is saved, whoever abandons it drowns.

10.layer5:
The rhetorical question in Surah al-Qaari'a 10, *"And what can make you know what that is?"* has prompted rich theological reflection across Islamic traditions. Both Sunni and Shia exegetes broadly concur that the verse emphasizes the inscrutable nature of *al-Qaari'a* (the Calamity or Day of Judgment), underscoring human limitation in comprehending divine realities. Al-Tabari (Sunni) and al-Tabrisi (Shia) alike note the verse’s linguistic structure as a rhetorical device amplifying awe, with al-Tabari stating it "confirms the magnitude of the event beyond human perception" (*Jami al-Bayan*), while al-Tabrisi echoes this in *Majma al-Bayan*, calling it a "reminder of creation’s inability to grasp divine judgment."  

Divergences emerge in theological framing. Sunni commentators like Ibn Kathir (*Tafsir al-Quran al-Azim*) and al-Qurtubi (*Al-Jami li-Ahkam*) anchor the verse in Allah’s absolute power, linking it to eschatological Hadiths describing the Day’s physical terrors. Al-Razi (*Mafatih al-Ghayb*) adds a philosophical layer, arguing the verse critiques human reliance on sensory knowledge. Shia sources, while affirming Allah’s transcendence, often integrate the verse into discourses on *ma‘rifa* (divine knowledge) accessible through the Imams. Al-Tabatabai (*Al-Mizan*) states the verse hints at truths "perceived only through divine revelation and the guidance of the Ahl al-Bayt," a theme echoed in al-Qummi’s esoteric readings (*Tafsir al-Qummi*).  

Historically, these differences reflect distinct epistemological frameworks: Sunni exegesis developed amid debates over divine attributes and human reason, while Shia interpretations evolved within narratives privileging the Imams’ role as inheritors of prophetic knowledge. Practically, the verse reinforces humility before divine mysteries for both traditions, though Shia theology may emphasize seeking guidance through the Imams’ teachings as a means to approach such truths. Both traditions ultimately unite in affirming the verse’s core purpose: to awaken reverence for the unseen divine order.

The verse "وَمَآ أَدْرَىٰكَ مَا هِيَهْ" (And what can make you know what that is?) from Surah Al-Qaari'a employs a rhetorical style common in early Meccan revelations, challenging human limitations in grasping divine realities. Revealed during intense opposition to the Prophet’s message, this surah focuses on the Day of Judgment – called *Al-Qaari'a* (The Striking Calamity) – to awaken its original audience to life’s transient nature and the certainty of resurrection. The repeated phrase "ما أدرىٰك" (what makes you know) underscores humanity’s inability to comprehend cosmic truths without divine guidance, a theme echoed in Shia exegesis like Allamah Tabatabai’s *Al-Mizan*, which notes that such verses humble human intellect while affirming the necessity of prophetic revelation. Imam Ali (as) taught, "The reality of the Hour is known only to the One who created it, but He has placed its keys in the hearts of His proofs [the Ahlul Bayt]. By internalising the lesson that "what makes you know" comes from Allah, Muslims nurture *tawakkul* (trust in God) while actively seeking knowledge through authentic religious sources.

11.layer1:
Surah Al-Qaari'a (The Striking Calamity) is a powerful Meccan chapter describing the Day of Judgment, with verse 11 declaring: *Narun Hamiyah* – "It is a Fire, intensely hot." This verse concludes a vivid depiction of the afterlife’s duality: while the righteous receive eternal joy (v. 6-7), those who rejected truth face this blazing punishment. The term *Nar* (Fire) appears frequently in the Quran as a symbol of divine justice, but *Hamiyah* intensifies it – derived from *hamiya* (to blaze), it signifies a heat beyond earthly comprehension, consuming both body and soul. Shia tafsir, like Allamah Tabatabai’s *Al-Mizan*, explains this as the inevitable consequence of accumulated spiritual neglect: hearts hardened by arrogance, greed, or oppression ignite their own suffering, mirroring their inner void of God-consciousness.

Revealed during Mecca’s persecution era, this verse challenged tribal elites who mocked resurrection. By naming the Fire’s ferocity, it dismantled their illusions of invincibility, urging self-reflection. Early Shia narrations, such as those from Imam Ali, stress that *Narun Hamiyah* isn’t merely physical but represents the agony of separation from divine mercy – a theme echoed in supplications like Dua Kumayl, which seek protection from "the fire that engulfs inward and outward."

For modern Muslims, this verse is a timeless call to balance hope in Allah’s mercy with consciousness of accountability. It cautions against moral complacency, reminding us that small ethical compromises – dishonesty, neglect of others’ rights, or apathy toward justice – can erode spiritual resilience. Practically, it inspires active self-reform (tazkiyah) and alignment with the Ahlul Bayt’s teachings on social responsibility and inner purity. Just as physical fire purifies gold, *Narun Hamiyah* symbolises the painful yet necessary consequences of unrepentant wrongdoing, urging believers to seek light (noor) through faith and righteous action before the scales of deeds (mawazin) are sealed.
11.layer2:
In interpreting Surah al-Qari'a verse 11 ("A Fire intensely hot"), classical Shia exegetes emphasise both the literal and metaphysical dimensions of this divine warning. Tabrisi in *Majma al-Bayan* contextualises this verse within the surah's eschatological framework, noting that the "crushing calamity" (al-qari'a) culminates in this blazing fire as the ultimate consequence for those whose scales of deeds are found wanting (v.8-9). He cites narrations attributing to Imam Jafar al-Sadiq the explanation that this fire "shall scorch their faces and penetrate their hearts," indicating both physical torment and spiritual devastation.

Tabatabai's *Al-Mizan* expands this through ontological analysis, arguing that the fire's intensity (hamiyah) reflects the existential weight of human choices. The term "hamiyah" – derived from hama (to blaze) – is interpreted as a self-fueling fire consuming souls who rejected divine guidance. This aligns with the Shia theological principle that hellfire constitutes the self-manifestation (tajalli) of one's spiritual state rather than arbitrary punishment, as articulated in Imam Ali's Nahj al-Balagha: "Today [the Day of Judgment] is the day of self-reckoning."

Shia commentators uniquely connect this verse to the doctrine of wilayah (divine guardianship). The intensity of punishment is understood to correlate with one's rejection of the Ahl al-Bayt's divinely ordained leadership, as their recognition constitutes the "heavy measure" (v.6) saving from this fate. Classical sources like Shaykh al-Saduq's *Al-I'tiqadat* frame the fire's heat as proportional to the soul's distance from the Muhammadan light embodied in the Imams.

Jurisprudentially, this verse underpins the Shia ethical framework where avoidance of hellfire necessitates adherence to both Quranic injunctions and the Ahl al-Bayt's teachings. The fire's description serves not merely as deterrent but as a call to ontological alignment with divine reality – a core theme in Shia soteriology where salvation hinges on conscious submission (islam) and loving allegiance (mawadda) to the Prophet's household.
11.layer3:
In contemporary Shia scholarship, Surah Al-Qaari’a’s depiction of a “Fire, intensely hot” (101:11) is interpreted through layered spiritual, ethical, and existential lenses. Ayatollah Nasir Makarem Shirazi, in his *Tafsir Nemuneh*, emphasises that this verse transcends literal hellfire, symbolising the *consequences of moral disintegration*—a theme resonant in an era of climate crisis, social inequity, and existential alienation. The “heat” here mirrors both the physical reality of global warming—a planet scorched by ecological negligence—and the metaphorical fever of societal greed, as noted by scholars like Dr. Mohammad Ali Shomali, who links consumerist excess to spiritual bankruptcy.  

Modern scientific analogies enrich this discourse: astrophysicists describe supernovae and black holes as cosmic “fires” of unfathomable heat, paralleling the Quranic imagery of divine power and the fragility of human systems. Philosophically, the verse challenges humanity’s anthropocentrism—a theme explored by contemporary thinkers like Dr. Liyakat Takim, who frames it as a call to humility amid technological hubris.  

Socially, the “intensely hot” fire critiques systemic injustices: the scorching reality of poverty, displacement, and war—issues amplified in Shia humanitarian theology. Interfaith dialogues, particularly with Christian eschatology and Hindu concepts of *agni* (sacred fire), find common ground in viewing fire as purifier and reckoner. In multicultural societies, this verse becomes a bridge for collective ethical action, urging unity against shared planetary crises. Ultimately, it’s a timeless warning: the fires we ignite—through exploitation or indifference—will define our hereafter, both metaphysically and in the world we leave behind.
11.layer4:
The blazing fire described in Surah Al-Qaari'a (101:11) is illuminated through the teachings of the Ahlul Bayt (peace be upon them) as both a physical reality and a spiritual metaphor. Imam Ali (peace be upon him) taught that Hellfire manifests not only in the hereafter but also in the soul's anguish when distanced from divine truth. In Tafsir al-Qummi, Imam Ja'far al-Sadiq (peace be upon him) explains this verse refers to "the fire ignited in hearts that rejected the guardianship (Wilayah) of the Ahlul Bayt" – a spiritual combustion born from willful alienation from the Imamah's light.

Lady Fatimah (peace be upon her) warned in her famed sermon: "The hottest fire is reserved for those who oppose Allah’s chosen ones." This aligns with Shia theology where recognizing divine leadership becomes the criterion for salvation. The "intensely hot" flames symbolize the compounded regret of those who ignored opportunities to spiritually elevate themselves through allegiance to the Imams. 

Imam Sadiq taught that believers must "extinguish the fire of heedlessness with the water of remembrance" – directing followers to counter spiritual entropy through daily communion with the Qur'an and supplications like Dua Kumayl. Practical protection from this inferno lies in nurturing the "coolness of certainty" (burudat al-yaqin) through:  
1. Regular mourning for Imam Hussain (peace be upon him), whose martyrdom cools hellfire for his lovers  
2. Seeking intercession via the Panjetan  
3. Internalizing the justice-oriented teachings of the Imams in social conduct  

The verse ultimately warns that hearts hardened against divine guidance through the Muhammadan light (Nur Muhammadi) risk becoming fuel for this eternal blaze. As Imam Ali advised in Nahj al-Balagha: "The fire you fear in the hereafter is but the shadow of the fire you kindle through your worldly choices.

سورہ القاری آیت 11 ("ایک آگ کی شدت سے گرم") کی ترجمانی کرتے ہوئے ، کلاسیکی شیعہ استثنیٰ اس الہی انتباہ کے لفظی اور استعاریاتی دونوں جہتوں پر زور دیتے ہیں۔ * ماجما البیان * میں تبریسی نے اس آیت کو سورہ کے ایسکیٹولوجیکل فریم ورک کے اندر سیاق و سباق میں پیش کیا ہے ، اور یہ نوٹ کیا ہے کہ "کرشنگ آف تباہی" (القیریہ) اس بھڑک اٹھنے والی آگ میں ان لوگوں کے لئے حتمی نتیجہ ہے جس کے اعمال کے ترازو مطلوب ہیں (v.8-9)۔ انہوں نے امام جعفر السادق سے منسوب بیانات کا حوالہ دیا ہے کہ اس آگ سے "ان کے چہروں کو بھڑکائے گا اور ان کے دلوں میں گھس جائے گا" ، جو جسمانی عذاب اور روحانی تباہی دونوں کی نشاندہی کرتا ہے۔

تبتابائی کا * المزان * اس کو آنٹولوجیکل تجزیہ کے ذریعہ وسعت دیتا ہے ، اور یہ استدلال کرتا ہے کہ آگ کی شدت (ہمیہ) انسانی انتخاب کے وجودی وزن کی عکاسی کرتی ہے۔ "ہمیہ" کی اصطلاح-جو حامہ (بلیز) سے ماخوذ ہے-کی ترجمانی ایک خود ایندھن والی آگ استعمال کرنے والی روحوں کے طور پر کی گئی ہے جنہوں نے خدائی رہنمائی کو مسترد کردیا۔ یہ شیعہ مذہبی اصول کے مطابق ہے کہ جہنم فائر کسی کی روحانی ریاست کی خود سے سنیومٹی (تاجلی) کو صوابدیدی سزا کی بجائے تشکیل دیتا ہے ، جیسا کہ امام علی کے نااہج البالھاگھا میں بیان کیا گیا ہے: "آج [فیصلے کا دن] خود سے ملنے کا دن ہے۔"

شیعہ مبصرین اس آیت کو منفرد طور پر ولیہ (الہی سرپرستی) کے نظریے سے مربوط کرتے ہیں۔ سزا کی شدت کو کسی کے اے ایچ ایل البائٹ کی خدائی مقررہ قیادت کو مسترد کرنے کے ساتھ وابستہ کرنا سمجھا جاتا ہے ، کیونکہ ان کی پہچان اس قسمت سے بچت "بھاری پیمائش" (V.6) کی تشکیل کرتی ہے۔ کلاسیکی ذرائع جیسے شیخ الصدق کی * الیئٹقادات * آگ کی حرارت کو محمدن کی روشنی سے روح کے فاصلے کے متناسب اماموں میں شامل ہیں۔

فقہی طور پر ، یہ آیت شیعہ اخلاقی فریم ورک کی نشاندہی کرتی ہے جہاں جہنم کی آگ سے بچنے کے لئے قرآنی احکامات اور اے ایچ ایل البائٹ کی تعلیمات دونوں پر عمل پیرا ہونے کی ضرورت ہوتی ہے۔ آگ کی تفصیل محض رکاوٹ کے طور پر نہیں بلکہ الہی حقیقت کے ساتھ آنٹولوجیکل سیدھ کی کال کے طور پر کام کرتی ہے۔

11.layer5:
In interpreting Surah Al-Qari'a 11 ("a Fire, intensely hot"), Shia and Sunni exegetes converge on core eschatological principles while diverging in theological emphasis. Both traditions universally acknowledge the verse’s literal depiction of Hell’s severity as a consequence for moral and spiritual failure. Al-Tabari (Sunni) and Al-Tabrisi (Shia) both contextualize the verse within the Quran’s broader Day of Judgment imagery, stressing its function as a deterrent against disbelief and injustice. Al-Qurtubi and Al-Tusi similarly highlight the fire’s physical and spiritual torment, reflecting shared Islamic eschatology.

Key differences emerge in theological framing. Sunni commentators like Ibn Kathir emphasize individual accountability for rejecting divine guidance, often linking the punishment to neglect of core obligations (e.g., prayer, charity). In contrast, Shia scholars such as Al-Tabatabai (Al-Mizan) situate the verse within the framework of divine justice (‘adl), interpreting the fire as a manifestation of self-inflicted spiritual alienation resulting from rejecting wilayah (devotion to the Ahl al-Bayt). Al-Qummi’s tafsir extends this by associating the "intensely hot" nature with the compounded weight of sins against both God and the Imams’ authority.

These interpretations subtly shape theological priorities: Sunni works like Al-Razi’s Mafatih al-Ghayb focus on God’s omnipotence in administering justice, while Shia exegesis intertwines eschatology with the necessity of Imamah. Historically, these divergences reflect early theological debates about leadership and moral authority post-Prophet Muhammad, with Shia sources integrating Imamah into their hermeneutics. Both traditions, however, maintain the verse’s practical aim: inspiring ethical vigilance through vivid eschatological imagery.

سورت القاری 11 ("ایک آگ ، شدت سے گرم") کی ترجمانی کرتے ہوئے ، شیعہ اور سنی نے مذہبی زور سے ہٹتے ہوئے بنیادی اسکیٹولوجیکل اصولوں پر تبادلہ خیال کیا۔ دونوں روایات عالمی سطح پر اخلاقی اور روحانی ناکامی کے نتیجے میں آیت کی جہنم کی شدت کی لفظی عکاسی کو تسلیم کرتی ہیں۔ التباری (سنی) اور الاتبریسی (شیعہ) دونوں قرآن مجید کے فیصلے کی منظر کشی کے وسیع دن کے اندر اس آیت کو سیاق و سباق دیتے ہیں ، اور کفر اور ناانصافی کے خلاف روکنے کے طور پر اس کے کام پر زور دیتے ہیں۔ القوروبی اور التوسی اسی طرح آگ کے جسمانی اور روحانی عذاب کو اجاگر کرتے ہیں ، جو مشترکہ اسلامی اسکاٹولوجی کی عکاسی کرتے ہیں۔

مذہبی ڈھانچے میں کلیدی اختلافات سامنے آتے ہیں۔ ابن کتھیر جیسے سنی مبصرین خدائی رہنمائی کو مسترد کرنے کے لئے انفرادی احتساب پر زور دیتے ہیں ، اکثر بنیادی ذمہ داریوں (جیسے دعا ، خیراتی ادارے) کو نظرانداز کرنے کی سزا کو جوڑ دیتے ہیں۔ اس کے برعکس ، شیعہ اسکالرز جیسے الاتعباتابائی (المزان) الہی انصاف (‘اے ڈی ایل) کے فریم ورک کے اندر آیت کو پیش کرتے ہیں ، اور آگ کی ترجمانی کرتے ہوئے ولیہ کو مسترد کرنے کے نتیجے میں خود سے متاثرہ روحانی بیگانگی کے مظہر کے طور پر (اے ایچ ایل ال بیت کی عقیدت) کے نتیجے میں۔ القومی کے طافسیر نے خدا اور اماموں کے اتھارٹی دونوں کے خلاف گناہوں کے پیچیدہ وزن کے ساتھ "انتہائی گرم" نوعیت کو جوڑ کر اس میں توسیع کی ہے۔

یہ تشریحات مکمل طور پر مذہبی ترجیحات کی تشکیل کرتی ہیں: سنی کام کی طرح کام کرتی ہے جیسے العزر کے مافاتیہ الغیب انصاف کے انتظام میں خدا کی ہر طرف توجہ مرکوز کرتے ہیں ، جبکہ شیعہ امامہ کی ضرورت کے ساتھ اسکیولوجی کو روکتا ہے۔ تاریخی طور پر ، یہ تغیرات قیادت اور اخلاقی اتھارٹی کے بعد کے حامی محمد کے بارے میں ابتدائی مذہبی مباحثوں کی عکاسی کرتے ہیں ، شیعہ ذرائع نے امامہ کو ان کے ہرمینیٹکس میں ضم کیا۔ تاہم ، دونوں روایات آیت کے عملی مقصد کو برقرار رکھتے ہیں: وشد اسکیٹولوجیکل امیجری کے ذریعہ اخلاقی نگرانی کو متاثر کرنا۔
11.summary: In interpreting Surah al-Qari'a verse 11 ("A Fire intensely hot"), classical Shia exegetes emphasise both the literal and metaphysical dimensions of this divine warning. Surah Al-Qaari'a (The Striking Calamity) is a powerful Meccan chapter describing the Day of Judgment, with verse 11 declaring: *Narun Hamiyah* – "It is a Fire, intensely hot. " This verse concludes a vivid depiction of the afterlife’s duality: while the righteous receive eternal joy (v. 6-7), those who rejected truth face this blazing punishment. Imam Ali (peace be upon him) taught that Hellfire manifests not only in the hereafter but also in the soul's anguish when distanced from divine truth. Just as physical fire purifies gold, *Narun Hamiyah* symbolises the painful yet necessary consequences of unrepentant wrongdoing, urging believers to seek light (noor) through faith and righteous action before the scales of deeds (mawazin) are sealed.
